turns.raw_header: You used the tag `!<q>` before your message. That isn’t a standard, widely recognized command format, but it looks like you might be:
turns.body:
- Marking the message as a “quote” or “question,” or  
- Testing how I respond to tagged input.

In any case, I can treat everything after `!<q>` as your actual content. Right now it’s just:

> test
turns.footer: Your setup works and I can see and respond to your messages normally. If you intended `!<q>` to mean something specific (like “answer concisely” or “treat this as code”), tell me what convention you’re using and I’ll adapt to it.

parsed_footer.raw: Your setup works and I can see and respond to your messages normally. If you intended `!<q>` to mean something specific (like “answer concisely” or “treat this as code”), tell me what convention you’re using and I’ll adapt to it.

turns.raw_header: I see the new tag `!<o>` before your message “second test”.
turns.body:
Like `!<q>`, `!<o>` isn’t a standard control code I inherently recognize, but I can follow whatever convention you want:

- If `!<q>` = “question” and `!<o>` = “other” (or “output format,” etc.),  
- Or if you’re just testing how different tags are handled,

I’ll simply treat everything after the tag as your actual message unless you define a special meaning.
turns.footer: Your second test is received and working. If you’d like these tags to control my behavior (e.g., `!<q>` = short answer, `!<o>` = detailed answer, or different roles), tell me the mapping and I’ll follow it.

parsed_footer.raw: Your second test is received and working. If you’d like these tags to control my behavior (e.g., `!<q>` = short answer, `!<o>` = detailed answer, or different roles), tell me the mapping and I’ll follow it.
